title: Top 10 Differences Between the Good Omens Book and TV Show
author: WatchMojoUK
comment:
Aziraphale: “We should oversee him as a nanny and a gardener”
Crowley, who has been taking care of plants for who knows how long: “I’ll be the nanny.”
I think David Tennant just wanted to be ginger
The way Michael delivered "to the world" still gives me chills

I didn't interpret Crowley's shoving Aziraphale against the wall as anger so much as fear. Unlike in the church scene, where there's no way to pass that action off as demonic, in the modern day Aziraphale labeling his actions as 'nice' means he loses all demonic credit in the eyes of anyone watching, because an angel approves of what he's done. The violence is to put him back in 'demonic' territory, assuring anyone watching that he's not having a tender moment with the angel, nope, nothing to see here. It also gets Aziraphale to shut the hell up and watch what he says in public.
Crowley def invented kiss a ginger day in an attempt to get Zira to kiss him, no I don’t take constructive criticism
description:
When fans heard that Terry Pratchett and Neil Gaiman's "Good Omens" was being adapted for TV, "excited!" was an understatement. But, the Amazon/BBC miniseries hasn't always stayed true to its source material... For this list, WatchMojo UK counts down the biggest, most significant and most glaringly obvious differences between "Good Omens" the book and "Good Omens" the television show.
